item.title: Install Arch Arm on Raspberry Pi
item.description: Start fdisk to partition the SD card: fdisk /dev/sdX At the fdisk prompt, delete old partitions and create a new one: Type o to clear out any partitions on the drive. Type p to list partitions. There should be no partitions left. Type n, then p for primary, 1 for the first partition on the drive, press ENTER to accept the default first sector, then type +100M for the last sector.
item.content:
1. Start fdisk to partition the SD card:

    fdisk /dev/sdX

  2. At the fdisk prompt, delete old partitions and create a new one:

    • Type o to clear out any partitions on the drive.
    • Type p to list partitions. There should be no partitions left.
    • Type n, then p for primary, 1 for the first partition on the drive, press ENTER to accept the default first sector, then type +100M for the last sector.
    • Type t, then c to set the first partition to type W95 FAT32 (LBA).
    • Type n, then p for primary, 2 for the second partition on the drive, and then press ENTER twice to accept the default first and last sector.
    • Write the partition table and exit by typing w.

  3. Create and mount the FAT filesystem:

    mkfs.vfat /dev/sdX1
mkdir boot
mount /dev/sdX1 boot

  4. Create and mount the ext4 filesystem:

    mkfs.ext4 /dev/sdX2
mkdir root
mount /dev/sdX2 root

  5. Download the ArchLinuxARM tar:

    wget http://os.archlinuxarm.org/os/ArchLinuxARM-rpi-<Raspberry-Pi-version>-latest.tar.gz

  6. Change to root and extract the root filesystem (do not use sudo):

    su
bsdtar -xpf ArchLinuxARM-rpi-<Raspberry-Pi-version>-latest.tar.gz -C root
sync

  7. Move boot files to the first partition:

    mv root/boot/* boot

  8. Unmount the two partitions:

    umount boot root

  9. Insert the SD card into the Raspberry Pi and boot up.

  10. Login as the default user alarm with the password alarm. The default root password is root.

  11. Initialize the pacman keyring and populate the Arch Linux ARM package signing keys:

    pacman-key --init
pacman-key --populate archlinuxarm

item.title: How to update git submodules
item.description: In your git repository you can have one or multiple others git repositories as submodule. To add a git repository as a submodule, use the following command: git submodule add <submodule git url> <local path to the submodule repository> To update all of the submodules, issues the following command: version >= 1.8.2 git submodule update --recursive --remote version >= 1.7.3 git submodule update --recursive or git pull --recurse-submodules Note: In case the repository is checked out for the first time, the --init option has to be used.
item.content:
In your git repository you can have one or multiple others git repositories as submodule. To add a git repository as a submodule, use the following command:

git submodule add <submodule git url> <local path to the submodule repository>

To update all of the submodules, issues the following command:

  • version >= 1.8.2

    git submodule update --recursive --remote
    • version >= 1.7.3
    git submodule update --recursive

    or

    git pull --recurse-submodules

    Note: In case the repository is checked out for the first time, the --init option has to be used.

    git submodule update --init --recursive

  • version < 1.7.3

    git submodule foreach git pull origin master

item.title: How to change the author of git commit
item.description: To change the author of a git commit, do the following: git rebase -i <commit-hash> git commit --amend --author="name <email@mail.com>" git rebase --continue
item.content:
To change the author of a git commit, do the following:

git rebase -i <commit-hash>
git commit --amend --author="name <email@mail.com>"
git rebase --continue

item.title: Create post with hugo
item.description: To create a post with hugo CLI, use hugo new .
item.content:
To create a post with hugo CLI, use

hugo new ./content/posts/my-first-post.md
